page.title: 16LUNAN. LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: HISTORIC MONUMENTS It is well worth the climb up the steep sided promontory on the south side of Lunan water, just where the river enters the sea, not just for the view but to inspect the ruins of RED CASTLE. The remains consist of a 13th century curtain wall and a 15th. century tower. The building is said to be on the site of a much earlier castle built for William the Lion by Walter de Berkley to counter the raids by Danish pirates.Lunan was at this time a royal hunting ground, a fact which is born out by the names of farms in the area e.g. Courthill and Hawkhill. At Imrie Crescent, Braehead of Lunan there is a 45feet OBELISK. This was erected in 1850 in memory of Lt.Col.James Blair of the Bengal Army.
